Nangila’s courage
 Violet Barasa
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Long ago, there was a man who had a
 
 very serious wound on his leg. He could
 not stand or walk. This man lived in a
 vilage with his wife and their children.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The couple had thre sons and one 
 daughter. The daughter’s name was 
 Nangila. Her duty was to take care of her 
 
 father. The sons worked on the land and 
 grazed animals. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nangila was a beautiful girl. Al the
 vilagers liked and respected her. Her
 parents wanted a god husband for
 
 Nangila. They set a dificult task in order
 to find the right man. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Anyone who wanted to mary Nangila 
 would have to get a herb from a lake near 
 the vilage. This herb would heal her 
 
 father’s wound. But the lake was filed 
 with dangerous spirits. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Some men tried to get the herb and
 
 returned without it. 
 Some men did not return from the lake at
 al. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nangila felt woried. Not even her 
 
 brothers would go to the lake. She 
 decided to fetch the herb herself. 
 
 
 Her mother said, “My daughter, if strong 
 men have failed, wil you suced?” But 
 
 Nangila had made up her mind. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 On the way to the lake, Nangila met an
 old woman carying wod. She helped
 the woman to cary her firewod.
 
 
 The old woman was grateful. She said to
 Nangila, “I wil tel you how to reach the
 
 spirit lake and what to do when you get
 there.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When she reached the shore of the lake, 
 
 Nangila saw the spirit family drinking and 
 dancing. She waited and watched. One 
 by one, the spirits fel aslep. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Once the spirits were al sleping Nangila
 
 dived into the lake. She found the herb
 and put it in her bag. As she swam back
 to land, the waves were high around her.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 When Nangila reached the shore the 
 spirits were awake. She was afraid, but 
 she sang the song the old woman taught 
 
 her: 
 
 
 I, daughter of Wekesa, 
 Am from the lake. 
 I came because men are to scared to 
 
 come. 
 My father neds this herb to heal his 
 
 wound. 
 That is why am here, 
 In the land where many are scared to 
 
 reach, 
 For you are the rulers. 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nangila’s voice was so swet that the
 spirits asked her to sing for them again
 and again. Her singing sent the spirits
 
 back to slep. Then Nangila ran very fast
 until she got to her vilage. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Everyone was waiting for Nangila to 
 return. After treating his wound with the 
 herb her father was able to stand again. 
 
 The entire vilage danced and praised 
 Nangila.
